title: General Knowledge Quiz VI (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair. New categories: Literature & Myth, Art & Architecture, Music & Performing Arts, Mathematics & Physics, Ancient Civilizations.

items.q: Which epic poem recounts Odysseus’s journey home after the Trojan War?
items.a: The Odyssey - epic attributed to Homer, sequel to the Iliad

items.q: In Greek tragedy, who unknowingly kills his father and marries his mother?
items.a: Oedipus - tragic king in Sophocles’ Oedipus Rex

items.q: Which medieval work follows Dante through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise?
items.a: The Divine Comedy - epic poem by Dante Alighieri

items.q: In Norse myth, what is the name of the world tree connecting the nine realms?
items.a: Yggdrasil - the cosmic ash tree of Norse cosmology

items.q: Which Spanish novel features a knight who tilts at windmills?
items.a: Don Quixote - satirical novel by Miguel de Cervantes

items.q: Who is the trickster god of Norse mythology, often a shapeshifter?
items.a: Loki - a complex figure associated with mischief and chaos

items.q: Which ancient Mesopotamian epic features a quest for immortality?
items.a: The Epic of Gilgamesh - one of the earliest known literary works

items.q: Who wrote the dystopian novel Brave New World?
items.a: Aldous Huxley - 1932 novel about a technologically controlled society

items.q: Which Greek poet is famed for lyrical poems addressed to love and beauty?
items.a: Sappho - poet from the island of Lesbos

items.q: What is the name of the Japanese poetic form consisting of 5-7-5 syllables?
items.a: Haiku - concise poetry form emphasizing nature and insight

items.q: Which architectural style is characterized by pointed arches and flying buttresses?
items.a: Gothic - exemplified by cathedrals like Chartres and Notre-Dame

items.q: Who designed the house known as Fallingwater in Pennsylvania?
items.a: Frank Lloyd Wright - icon of organic architecture built over a waterfall

items.q: Which art movement was founded by Walter Gropius in 1919 Germany?
items.a: Bauhaus - a school integrating art, craft, and industry

items.q: What is the name of the marble statue of David completed in 1504?
items.a: David - masterpiece by Michelangelo now in Florence’s Accademia

items.q: Which Dutch artist painted Girl with a Pearl Earring?
items.a: Johannes Vermeer - c. 1665 oil painting noted for light and stillness

items.q: The Parthenon on the Acropolis exemplifies which column order?
items.a: Doric - simplest of the three classical Greek orders

items.q: Who is the Spanish surrealist known for melting clocks in The Persistence of Memory?
items.a: Salvador Dalí - 1931 painting exploring dreamlike imagery

items.q: Which architect coined the phrase 'Less is more'?
items.a: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe - modernist architect of minimalism

items.q: What is the art technique of painting on fresh wet plaster called?
items.a: Fresco - pigments chemically bond as the plaster dries

items.q: Which movement featured artists like Claude Monet focusing on light and momentary effects?
items.a: Impressionism - late 19th‑century art movement in France

items.q: Which composer wrote Symphony No. 9 featuring the 'Ode to Joy' chorus?
items.a: Ludwig van Beethoven - landmark choral symphony in D minor

items.q: Which Italian opera by Verdi tells the story of Violetta and Alfredo?
items.a: La Traviata - debuted in 1853 at La Fenice in Venice

items.q: What is the name of Shakespeare’s theater on London’s South Bank (modern reconstruction)?
items.a: The Globe Theatre - open‑air playhouse associated with Shakespeare

items.q: Which Russian composer wrote The Nutcracker ballet?
items.a: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky - Christmas‑season ballet premiered in 1892

items.q: Which instrument family includes the oboe, clarinet, and bassoon?
items.a: Woodwinds - produce sound via air vibrating within the instrument

items.q: What is the musical term for a tempo that gradually slows down?
items.a: Ritardando - an instruction to decrease the tempo

items.q: Which American composer wrote the opera Porgy and Bess?
items.a: George Gershwin - 1935 folk opera with jazz and classical elements

items.q: Which voice type is higher: tenor or baritone?
items.a: Tenor - sits above baritone in the male vocal range

items.q: What is the term for a recurring musical theme associated with a character or idea?
items.a: Leitmotif - technique famously used by Richard Wagner

items.q: Which jazz trumpeter is nicknamed 'Satchmo'?
items.a: Louis Armstrong - pioneering figure in early jazz and scat singing

items.q: What mathematical constant is approximately 3.14159?
items.a: Pi (π) - ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter

items.q: What is the SI unit of force?
items.a: Newton (N) - equals 1 kg·m·s⁻² by definition

items.q: What temperature corresponds to absolute zero on the Kelvin scale?
items.a: 0 K - equivalent to −273.15 °C, the lowest thermodynamic limit

items.q: What principle states E = mc²?
items.a: Mass–energy equivalence - Einstein’s relation linking mass and energy

items.q: Numbers divisible only by 1 and themselves are called what?
items.a: Primes - building blocks of integers via unique factorization

items.q: What is Avogadro’s constant (nearest 3 s.f.)?
items.a: 6.02×10^23 mol⁻¹ - number of particles per mole (exact: 6.02214076×10^23)

items.q: Which gas makes up ~21% of Earth’s atmosphere?
items.a: Oxygen - second most abundant gas after nitrogen

items.q: Which thought experiment involves a paradoxical alive‑and‑dead cat?
items.a: Schrödinger’s cat - highlights quantum superposition

items.q: Light in vacuum travels fastest at about how many km/s?
items.a: ≈300,000 km/s - the constant c (exactly 299,792.458 km/s)

items.q: What is the name for the study of shapes, sizes, and properties of space?
items.a: Geometry - branch of mathematics dating back to Euclid

items.q: Which ancient city was buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE?
items.a: Pompeii - Roman city preserved under volcanic ash

items.q: Which civilization built the ziggurat of Ur?
items.a: Sumerians - early Mesopotamian civilization

items.q: Which ancient empire built the Royal Road across western Asia?
items.a: Achaemenid (Persian) Empire - facilitated trade and communication

items.q: What was the primary language of the Roman Empire’s administration?
items.a: Latin - official language of law and governance

items.q: Which Egyptian pharaoh is associated with the monotheistic Aten cult?
items.a: Akhenaten - promoted worship of Aten in the Amarna period

items.q: Which ancient Greek city‑state was famed for military discipline?
items.a: Sparta - society organized around a warrior ethos

items.q: Which Carthaginian general crossed the Alps to fight Rome?
items.a: Hannibal Barca - key commander in the Second Punic War

items.q: Which writing system did the Phoenicians popularize across the Mediterranean?
items.a: Alphabetic script - an abjad influencing Greek and Latin

items.q: Which Mesoamerican civilization built the city of Chichén Itzá?
items.a: The Maya - known for stepped pyramids and astronomy

items.q: Who was the Athenian statesman who led during the city’s Golden Age?
items.a: Pericles - championed democracy and sponsored the Parthenon
